questions.question: According to the slides, what is a computational problem?
options: A bug in a computer program.
A specification of the output as a function of a specified input.
Any task that requires a computer to perform calculations.
The study of how to build efficient computers.

questions.question: What is the name given to the abstraction (a sequence of steps) designed to solve a computational problem?
options: A Data Structure
A Function
An Algorithm
A Specification

questions.question: Why is the efficiency of an algorithm important?
options: Because it makes the code easier to read.
Because computer resources are limited and need to be used economically.
Because inefficient algorithms are always incorrect.
Efficiency is not important if the algorithm produces the correct output.

questions.question: What two primary resources must an efficient algorithm be economical on?
options: CPU and GPU usage.
Space (memory) and Running Time.
Network bandwidth and Storage.
Developer time and Electricity.

questions.question: The efficiency of an algorithm fundamentally depends on what?
options: The programming language it is written in.
The speed of the computer's processor.
How the data is organised in memory (the data structure).
The size of the monitor used to view the output.

questions.question: What is the best definition of a 'Data Structure' from the options below?
options: A large database for storing information.
The way data is organised so it can be effectively used by a program to efficiently solve problems.
A collection of variables of the same type.
The physical hardware inside a computer that stores data.

questions.question: In the 'search problem' described, what are the inputs?
options: An algorithm and a data structure.
A set of items A and an item x to search for.
A linked list and a binary search tree.
The running time and memory space.

questions.question: What is a significant limitation of determining algorithm efficiency experimentally (by implementing and running it)?
options: It is always mathematically inaccurate.
It is too fast and doesn't provide useful data.
The algorithm has to be implemented, and you are limited to testing on specific input sizes and platforms.
It cannot measure the worst-case scenario.

questions.question: What is the best-case scenario for searching for an item in a linked list?
options: The item is not in the list.
The item is stored in the middle node.
The item is stored in the last node.
The item is stored in the first node.

questions.question: In the worst-case scenario for searching a linked list of one million nodes, how many comparisons might be needed?
options: Approximately 20 (log2(1,000,000))
It is impossible to know without running the program.

questions.question: According to the slides, what is the main goal of studying data structures?
options: To learn every programming language.
To understand how to choose the right data structure and algorithm to use resources efficiently.
To learn how to build faster computer hardware.
To memorize the syntax for declaring arrays and lists.

questions.question: What is a common use case for a Linked List, as mentioned in the slide?
options: To store items that need to be processed in a Last-In-First-Out (LIFO) order.
To store items that are to be processed sequentially.
To store items that need to be quickly searched using a divide-and-conquer approach.
To store key-value pairs for fast lookup.

questions.question: What is each spot on a Linked List called?
options: A Leaf
A Root
A Node
An Element

questions.question: What two pieces of information does a single node in a singly Linked List typically hold?
options: An item of data and a reference to the previous node.
An item of data and two references to child nodes.
An item of data and a reference to the next node.
Only an item of data.

questions.question: How is a Binary Search Tree organized, according to the slide?
options: Like a sequential chain of nodes.
Like a circular buffer.
Like an upside-down tree.
Like a hash table.

questions.question: What is the single node at the top of a BST called?
options: The Head Node
The Root Node
The Parent Node
The Primary Node

questions.question: Besides the data item, what do the nodes in a BST contain?
options: A single pointer to the next node.
A left pointer and a right pointer.
A reference to the parent node and a list of child nodes.
A priority value and a color flag.

questions.question: Which of the following is NOT listed as an example of a data structure in the slide?
options: Arrays
Stacks
Functions
Graphs

questions.question: The study of data structures covers systematic methodologies for determining what?
options: The cost of cloud computing services.
The popularity of different programming languages.
The efficiency of algorithms operating on those data structures.
The history of computer science.
